block.p: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
MUSIC

CHALFONTE HOTEL ''For Me. . .Formidable!'' cabaret of French songs, featuring Jilline Ringle. Through Sept. 17. Performances are at 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings. Tickets: $20; $18 for students and older people; $8 for children under 12. 301 Howard Street, Cape May. (609) 884-8409.
FAIR LAWN SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL Community dancing to the music of Tubby Tubello. Tonight, 8:30 p.m. to 10 p.m.. Free. Memorial Park, Berdan Avenue, Fair Lawn. (201) 796-6746.

An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
MUSIC

CHALFONTE HOTEL ''For Me. . .Formidable!'' cabaret of French songs, featuring Jilline Ringle. Through Sept. 17. Performances are at 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings. Tickets: $20; $18 for students and older people; $8 for children under 12. 301 Howard Street, Cape May. (609) 884-8409.
FAIR LAWN SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL Community dancing to the music of Tubby Tubello. Tonight, 8:30 p.m. to 10 p.m.. Free. Memorial Park, Berdan Avenue, Fair Lawn. (201) 796-6746.
FREE PUBLIC LIBRARY OF ELIZABETH ''Program of Song,'' featuring Elissa Weiss. Saturday at 2:15 p.m. 11 South Broad Street, Elizabeth. (908) 354-6060.
LONG BEACH ISLAND FOUNDATION OF THE ARTS AND SCIENCES ''Family Songs from Mamota,'' featuring Andrew Roblin. Saturday at 7 p.m. 120 Long Beach Boulevard, Loveladies. (609) 494-1241, extension 300.
MEYERSVILLE INN Vince Giantomasi Quartet. Friday, 6:30 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. 62 Meyersville Road, Meyersville. (908) 647-6302.
MINSTREL COFFEEHOUSE Josh Joffen and Relative Sight. Friday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $5. Morris County Park Commission's Cultural Center, 300 Mendham Road, Morristown. (973) 335-9489.

MONMOUTH COUNTY LIBRARY ''Spanish and Hispanic Music -- Two Part Concert,'' featuring Ovidiu Marinescu, cellist, and Chiu-Tze Lin, pianist. Next Sunday at 2 p.m. Free. 125 Symmes Drive, Manalapan. (732) 431-7242.

NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER Theo Lieven and William Grant Nabore, duo pianists, with The New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony, Kenneth Klein, conductor. Saturday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $25. Victoria Theater. 1 Center Street, Newark. (888) 466-5722.
NORTH WILDWOOD SUMMER SERIES Cozy Morley. Thursday at 8 p.m. The Dubs. Saturday at 8 p.m. Free. North Wildwood's amphitheater, Ocean and Second Avenues. Free. (609) 889-2241.

OCEAN GROVE SUMMER CONCERT SERIES Through Saturday. Father Alphonse and the Orchestra of St. Peter's By The Sea. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $22 (reserved); $17 (general admission). The Great Auditorium, Ocean Grove. (732) 988-0645.
OUTPOST IN THE BURBS Greg Brown. Friday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $ 16 (advance); $18 (day of the show). 40 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair. (973) 744-6560.
REGGAE ROOTS 2000 Shayar and Kroo'shall Force, Stormy, Afaya and Cate' and Shades of Rhythm. Saturday at 2 p.m. Nishuane Park, Harrison and Orange Road, Montclair. (973) 509-4910.
ROWAN UNIVERSITY Trace Adkins. Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $22, $25 and $28. Pfleeger Concert Hall, Wilson Hall, Glassboro Center for the Arts, Route 322, Glassboro. (856) 256-4545.

SHANGHAI JAZZ Bucky Pizzarelli, jazz. Wednesday at 7 p.m. Morris Nanton Trio, jazz. Thursday at 6:45 and 8:30 p.m. Santi Debriano ''Circle Chant'' Quartet. Friday at 6:45 and 8:30 p.m.; Saturday at 6:30 and 8:45 p.m. No cover. 24 Main Street, Madison. (973) 822-2899.

STANHOPE HOUSE Blue Sparks from Hell. Today at 9 p.m. Tickets: $10. Steve Forbert. Thursday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $12. Shade Tree Mechanics Blues Band. Friday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $7. Blues Power Blues Society presents three bands: Filthy Rich and the Poor Boys, Big Mike and the Perpetrators and Lady Blue and the Tramps. Saturday at 9 p.m. Tickets: $9. 45 Main Street, Stanhope. (973) 347-0458.
WATCHUNG ARTS CENTER Watchung Jim Wellen, saxophonist, and Rio Clemente. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Watchung Circle, 18 Stirling Road, Watchung. (908) 753-0190.
THEATER

BERGEN COUNTY PLAYERS ''Oliver!'' Saturday through Oct. 7. Fridays and Saturdays at 8:30 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $18. The Little Firehouse Theater, 298 Kinderkamack Road, Oradell. (201) 261-4200.

HUNTERDON HILLS PLAYHOUSE ''Razzmatazz,'' musical celebrating popular songs of the 20th century. Through Saturday. Monday through Saturday luncheon matinees beginning at 11 a.m.; Saturday at 6:30 p.m.; today at 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $39.50 to $51 (includes show and lunch/dinner). Exit 12 off Routes 78 and 22, Perryville. (800) 447-7313.
LUMIA THEATER ''Amnesia Wars.'' Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m.; Sept. 15 and 16, 10 p.m. Tickets: $10. 179 Broadway, Long Branch. (732) 229-3166.
NEW JERSEY SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL ''Antony and Cleopatra.'' Tuesday through Sept. 30. Tickets: $21 to $38. F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater, 36 Madison Avenue, Madison. (973) 408-5600.

PAPER MILL PLAYHOUSE ''Anything Goes'' starring Chita Rivera and Lee Roy Reams. Wednesday through Oct. 15. Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 p.m.; Thursday and Sunday matinees at 2 p.m.; and Saturday matinees at 2:30 p.m. Tickets: $37 to $60. Brookside Drive, Millburn. (973) 376-4343.

PLAYHOUSE 22 ''Once Upon a Mattress.'' Friday through Oct. 7. Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sunday matinees at 3 p.m. Tickets: $16; $12 for students and older people. 210 Dunhams Corner Road, East Brunswick. (732) 254-3939.

RITZ THEATER ''Vaudeville Villains,'' comedy by Alex Wilkie. Thursday through Oct. 7. Performances are Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m.; Wednesdays, Sept. 20 and Oct. 4 at 7:30 p.m.; preview performance Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $16 (Fridays and Saturdays); $12.50 (Sundays); $15 (Wednesdays); $10 (preview). 915 White Horse Pike, Oaklyn. (609) 858-5230.

STUDIO PLAYHOUSE ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying!'' Friday through Sept. 23. Friday and Saturday performances at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 5 p.m. Tickets: $15. 14 Alvin Place, Upper Montclair. (973) 744-9752.

TWELVE MILES WEST THEATRE COMPANY ''Shakespear's R+J,'' adapted by Joe Calarco. Thursday through Sept. 30. Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20; $15 for students and older people. (973) 746-7181.
TWO RIVER THEATER COMPANY ''Arms and the Man.'' Thursday through Sept. 24. Call for show times. Tickets: $19 to $34. Algonquin Arts Theater, 171 Main Street, Manasquan. (732) 345-1400.

VAGABOND PLAYERS ''Broadway's Best,'' a musical revue of some of the best songs Broadway has to offer this year. Saturday through Sept. 24. Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $10; $8 for children under 12 and older people.Shore Hills Country Club, Morse Place, Landing. (973) 398-3565.
MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES

ABC GALLERY ''The Fruits of My Labor, Oil Paintings and Pastels by Fern Blumberg.'' Through Sept. 29. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 1 to 9 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Lambertville Public Library, 6 Lilly Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-0275.

AMERICAN LABOR MUSEUM ''9th Annual Grand Parade'' celebrating the American worker. Today at 1:30 p.m. ''Workers' Portraits,'' photodocumentary exhibit by Robert Gumpert. Through Dec. 31. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; other times by appointment. Botto House National Landmark, 83 Norwood Street, Haledon. (973) 595-7953.

ARTISTS' GALLERY Bernard Ungerleider, paintings, and Bernard Mangiaracina, sculptures. Friday through Oct. 1. Opening reception: Saturday, 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. Hours: Fridays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. 32 Coryell Street, Lambertville. (609) 397-4588.

BARRON ARTS CENTER The Camera Arts Group exhibit. Friday through Oct. 1. Opening reception: Friday, 7:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. 582 Rahway Avenue, Woodbridge. (732) 634-0413.

BRION GALLERIES ''Impressions of New Jersey: Beauty, Botany and Everyday People of the Garden State.'' ''Visions in Mexico: Oil Paintings by Nina Wisniewski.'' Through Sept. 24. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. 1293 Route 179, Lambertville. (609) 397-7030.

CHALFONTE HOTEL ''Drawn to the Sea,'' watercolors by Alice Steer Wilson. Today through Oct. 15. Opening reception: today, 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. Solarium and Magnolia Rooms, 301 Howard Street, Cape May. (609) 884-8409.
CHAMOT GALLERY ''From Pop to the Millennium: 40 Years of Bill Barrell.'' Through Sept. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. 111 First Street, Jersey City. (201) 610-1468.

DRUE CHRYST GALLERY Elaine Kurie, oil still lifes and landscapes. Through Sept. 30. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; or by appointment. 21 White Deer Plaza, Lake Mohawk, Sparta. (973) 729-0609.

EXTENSION GALLERY Atelier Members' Exhibit, ''Sculptures Created in or Incorporating Stone.'' Tuesday through Oct. 5. Opening reception: Saturday, 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; other times by appointment. 60 Ward Avenue Extension, Mercerville. (609) 890-7777.

J.C.C. ON THE PALISADES ''Yemenite Jews: The Last Generation'' photographic exhibition. Thursday through Sept. 29. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 9 a.m to 10 p.m.; Friday and Sunday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. 411 East Clinton Avenue, Tenafly. (201) 569-7900, extension 433.

JERSEY CITY MUSEUM ''The Prints of a Sculptor,'' by Melvin Edwards. Through Oct. 7. Hours: Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Wednesdays, 10:30 a.m.to 8 p.m. 472 Jersey Avenue, Jersey City. (201) 547-4514.

MERCER COUNTY COMMUNITY COLLEGE ''Narrative Stance,'' exhibition of two Mercer County artists, Loring Hughes of Lawrenceville and Thomas Kelly of Trenton. Through Sept. 28. Hours: Mondays, 12:30 to 3 p.m.; Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Wednesdays and Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. and 6 to 8 p.m. The Gallery, Communications Center, 1200 Old Trenton Road, Trenton. (609) 586-4800, extension 3588.

MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM ''Native Soil: Art and the American Land.'' ''Georgia O'Keefe: The Artist's Landscape.'' Next Sunday through Jan. 7, 2001. ''Croquet: The Art of Play.' Through Oct. 15. Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 7 p.m.; Saturday through Oct. 15, course will be open Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $4 for children. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4 for older people and students; free for members and children under 12. 3 South Mountain Avenue, Montclair. (973) 746-5555.

MORRIS COUNTY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''1900,'' exhibit of photos, products and objects. Through September. Hours: Mondays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students. Acorn Hall, 68 Morris Avenue, Morristown. (973) 267-3465.

MORRIS MUSEUM New Jersey Arts Annual: ''Everything for the Home'' juried exhibition. Through Nov. 17. ''A Collector's Vision: Selections From the Collections of Edmund W. Pease and Nurak Israsena.'' Through Sept. 17. Hours: Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for older people and children under age 3. 6 Normandy Heights Road, Morristown. (973) 538-0454.

MUSEUM OF EARLY TRADES AND CRAFTS ''Time Made Visible: An Exhibit on Time and Timepieces.'' Through Dec. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $3.50; $2 for students, children over 5 and older people. Main Street at Green Village Road, Madison. (973) 377-2982.

NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY ''Dining In, Dining Out,'' featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks. Through summer 2001. ''Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles,'' about the history of baseball in Newark. Through summer 2001. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. 52 Park Place, Newark. (973) 596-8500.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Katherine Choy: A Promise Unfulfilled'' ceramic showcase. Through Jan. 7. ''Treasures of 19th Century American Art.'' Wednesday through Dec. 3. ''Wetlands.'' Through Sept. 17. ''2000 New Jersey Fine Arts Annual: Into the Millennium.'' Through Sept. 17. ''The Luminous Image, V,'' and exhibition of illuminated photography. Through Oct. 8. ''Year of the Dragon: The Calligraphy of Wang Fangyu.'' Through Nov. 12. ''Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning.'' Through December. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays (after hours) until 8:30 p.m. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6550.

NOYES MUSEUM OF ART ''Capturing the Jersey Shore: Works of Anthony J. Rudisill.'' Through next Sunday. ''Art in Boxes: Hers and His Stories.'' Saturday through Jan. 7, 2001. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for older people and students. Lily Lake Road, Oceanville. (609) 652-8848.

PATERSON MUSEUM ''Up on Two Wheels: A Look Back at Motorcycling in North Jersey,'' show includes antique, classic, military, police, American, Japanese and European models. Through Sept. 24. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 12:30 to 4:30 p.m. 2 Market Street, Paterson. (973) 881-3839.

PRINTMAKING COUNCIL OF NEW JERSEY ''Dust Shaped Hearts'' by Don Camp -- A Collection of casein and earth pigment monoprints.'' ''Ulysses Suite'' by Julyen Norman -- woodcuts, and linoleum cuts depicting scenes from the classic novel by James Joyce. Friday through Oct. 14. Opening reception: Friday, 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays, 1 to 4 p.m. 440 River Road, North Branch. (908) 725-2110.

J. RICHARDS GALLERY Dominigue Dorie, landscapes of Europe. Saturday through Oct. 5. Opening reception: Saturday, 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. 64 East Palisade Avenue, Englewood. (201) 871-1050.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - CAMDEN ''Every Picture Tells a Story,'' an exhibit that explores storytelling through narrative art. Tuesday through Nov. 11. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free. Stedman Gallery, Third Street between Cooper Street and Benjamin Franklin Bridge, Camden. (856) 225-6350.

RUTGERS UNIVERSITY - NEWARK ''Carrie Yamaoka: New Paintings.'' Through Oct. 13. Robeson Center Art Gallery, 350 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd, Newark. Hours: Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 4 p.m. (973) 353-5119, ext. 32. Prints and Drawings by Anaida Hernandez, 1989-1999. Through September. Hours: Monday through Thursday, 8 a.m. to midnight; Friday, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 10 p.m. Dana Library, 185 University Avenue, Newark. (973) 353-5900.

SIMON GALLERY Larry Deyab and Katherine Parker, paintings. Tuesday through Oct. 7. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m.; other times by appointment. 48 Bank Street, Morristown. (973) 538-5456.

SUMEI MULTIDISCIPLINARY ARTS CENTER ''Cuba: The Illusive Island.'' Saturday through Oct. 14. Hours: Wednesdays, 1 p.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.;or call for appointment. 19 Liberty Street, at the corner of Lafayette Street, Newark. (973) 643-7883.

SWAIN GALLERIES ''People, Places and Things'' pastels by Frank Zuccarelli. Saturday through Sept. 30. Opening reception: Saturday, 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays, 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. 703 Watchung Avenue, Plainfield. (908) 756-1707.

TRENTON CITY MUSEUM ''TAWA (Trenton Artists Workshop Association) Two Thousand.'' Through Sept. 24. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Sundays, 2 to 4 p.m. Ellarslie, Cadwalader Park, Trenton. (609) 989-3632.

WHEATON VILLAGE ''American Glass: 1900-2000,'' featuring more than 100 industrial and decorative pieces. Through Oct. 22. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $7; $6 for older people; $3.50 for students. No admission charge to the Gallery of American Craft. Exit 26, Route 55, Millville. (800) 998-4552, extension 2756.
FOR CHILDREN
EATONTOWN PLAYHOUSE ''The Fun-derful World of Mary Poppins.'' Saturday at 3 p.m. For ages 4 to 7. Tickets: $7.50. 37 Highway 35 North, Tower Shopping Center, Eatontown. (732) 460-0100.
FORUM THEATER COMPANY ''Stuart Little.'' Friday, Sept. 16 and Sept. 23 at 11 a.m. Tickets: $9. 314 Main Street, Metuchen. (732) 548-0582.

NEWARK MUSEUM ''Where in the Universe Is Carmen Sandiego?'' at the Alice and Leonard Dreyfuss Planetarium. Through October. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays at 2:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 p.m. and 3 p.m. Tickets: $3; $2 for members; $1 for children and older people. 49 Washington Street, Newark. (973) 596-6355.

TRAILSIDE NATURE AND SCIENCE CENTER ''Lake Surprise Stroll.'' Today at 2 p.m. Donations accepted.Planetarium Show. Next Sunday at 2 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. Fee: $3; $2.55 for older people. Pre-registration is required. 452 New Providence Road, Mountainside. (908) 789-3670.
SPOKEN WORD

BORDERS BOOKS AND MUSIC Andrew Stone, author, will discuss and sign copies of his book, ''All Flowers Die.'' Stone, a musician, also will perform. Friday at 8 p.m. Free. 601 Nassau Park Boulevard, Building G, Princeton. (609) 514-0040.

ENGLEWOOD PUBLIC LIBRARY Jane Leonard, librarian, will head the Mystery Book Discussion Group, focusing on ''A Common Death,'' Natasha Cooper's 1990 novel. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Free. 31 Engle Street, Englewood. (201) 568-2215, ext. 227.

MUSEUM OF EARLY TRADES AND CRAFTS Dr. David Sperling, clock collector, historian and lecturer, will speak on ''The Development of Clockmaking in New Jersey, 1700-1850.'' Wednesday at 6:30 p.m. Tickets: $10; $8 for members; $5 for University students. A short reception will follow the lecture. Main Street at Green Village Road, Madison. (973) 377-2982.
ETC.

ATLANTIC CITY IN-POWER BOAT SHOW Featuring more than 300 power boats, including sport yachts, sport fishing yachts and performance boats. Thursday and Friday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturday and next Sunday, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Tickets: $10; $5 for children 5 to 12. Farley State Marina, adjacent to Trump Marina Hotel Casino. (215) 732-8001.

FESTA ITALIANA Food, rides, lottery, games and music. Thursday, 6 p.m. to 11 p.m.; Friday, 4 p.m. to 11 p.m.; Saturday and next Sunday, 3 p.m. to 11 p.m. Our Lady of Mount Virgin Church, on the church grounds and surrounding streets of MacArthur Avenue and Frederick Street, Garfield. (973) 660-6878.

FLAT ROCK BROOK NATURE CENTER Sunset Hikes. Tuesdays in September at 6:30 p.m. Fall strolls. Wednesday mornings through November, 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. Fee: $3 for non-members; free for members.Pre-registration required. 443 Van Nostrand Avenue, Englewood. (201) 567-1265.

HOME OFFICE EXPO 2000 More than 80 exhibitors to provide the latest in home office technology, products and services. Saturday and next Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $15. Meadowlands Expo Center, Secaucus. (800) 243-9774.

NEW JERSEY FILM FESTIVAL FALL 2000 ''The Filth and the Fury.'' Friday through next Sunday at 7 p.m. Scott Hall, 123. Rutgers University, College Avenue and Hamilton Street, New Brunswick. Tickets: $5; $4 for members.(732) 932-8482.
RUTHERFORD STREET FAIR Forty civic organizations and 150 antiques and collectibles dealers. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. 5 p.m. Free. Park Avenue, from Ames Avenue into Lincoln Park. (212) 255-0020.

SOMERSET COUNTY PARK COMMISSION ''Galapagos: Its Land and Its Creatures -- A Photographic Exhibit.'' Saturday through Oct. 10. Hours: 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Free. Visitor Center, 190 Lord Stirling Road, Basking Ridge. (908) 766-2489.
AT THE CASINOS
All tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

BALLY'S PARK PLACE ''Legends in Concert,'' impersonations of Stevie Wonder, Little Richard, Elvis Presley, Linda Ronstadt and Barbara Streisand. Mondays through Thursdays at 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Saturdays at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; Sundays at 7:30 and 10 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $25. Park Cabaret, Boardwalk and Park Place. (800) 225-5977.

CLARIDGE HOTEL ''Little Anthony and the Imperials.'' Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $35. ''Pump Boys and Dinettes,'' national tour of the Broadway musical. Through Sept. 24. Performances are Mondays through Thursdays at 8 p.m.; Saturdays at 9 p.m.; next Sunday at 3 p.m. and 7 p.m. Tickets: $15, Sundays through Thursdays; $19, Saturdays. Palace Theater, Boardwalk and Park Place. (609) 340-3700.

SANDS HOTEL AND CASINO Bud Noble. Today, 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. Beth Ciotta Trio. Today, 10:15 p.m. to 2:15 a.m. Copa Lounge. Free. The Diamonds. Through next Sunday. Call for times. Tickets: $15. Indiana Avenue and Brighton Park. (609) 441-4137.

TROPICANA Randy Travis in Concert. Today at 7 p.m. Tickets: $55 (orchestra); $45 (mezzanine); $30 (balcony). Latin Fever Revue. Through Sept. 21. Call for times. Tickets: $9.90. ''Titanic: The Return,'' all new exhibition with more than 250 artifacts. Through Saturday. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Tickets: $14.95; $6.95 for children, ages 5 to 11. Grand Exhibition Center, fourth floor, South Tower. Boardwalk and Brighton Avenue. (609) 340-4020.
TRUMP MARINA Shawn Wayans. Today at 9 p.m. Tickets: $30 and $40. Grand Cayman. Huron Avenue and Brigantine Boulevard. (800) 777-8477.
TRUMP TAJ MAHAL Gipsy Kings. Friday at 10 p.m. Tickets: $35 to $100. Mark G. Etess Arena. 1000 Boardwalk. (609) 449-1000.
ON THE TOWNS
